subject: Marketing
title: The Editing Razor
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Editing Razor.

hook.text: Mark Twain said: 'I didn't have time to write a short letter, so I wrote a long one instead.'

buildup.text: First drafts are always too long. Great copy is created in the editing, not the writing.

discovery.text: Every word that doesn't earn its place weakens the words around it.

twist.text: Cutting 50% of a draft often makes it twice as persuasive. Less really is more.

climax.text: The editing razor asks one question of every word: does this move the reader toward action?

punchline.text: Write everything. Then cut half. Then cut half again.

quiz.question: Why does cutting copy often make it more persuasive?
options: Every unnecessary word weakens the words around it
Shorter copy is always ranked higher by search engines
Readers only trust content under 100 words
